Posts.Content: SofieKatz wrote: I got my third dose of A/C 5 days ago.  Am I supposed to feel worse side effects with each dose?  Last time I recovered faster.  Now I hurt in places I didn't hurt before, and the nausea is lingering longer.  This is cumulative?    I get my last dose of A/C two weeks from Friday.  Then, Taxol weekly for 12 weeks.  I am not a trooper.  I am tired of this, crabby and humorless.  My oncologist said A/C would be tough, and Taxol would be much easier, but now I am reading here how Taxol also is difficult.  There is so much I am not getting done.     Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2012 05:45AM SofieKatz wrote: I was more upset about losing my hair than any other element of the BC hijacking. (I don't call it a journey.  It's more like a hijack, or abduction). I was horrified when my hair fell out.  The first time I wore my wig I went to a TJMax and Home Goods store, to see if anyone noticed.  No one noticed. The only people who checked me out were the other women at the infusion center.  Not in a bad way.  Just a glance and they'd move on.
Posts.Title: Why am I so ashamed of my hair loss? JoanQuilts DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 10:28AM SofieKatz wrote: Hi, I work for an organization that sends therapy dogs to facilities where people need comfort.  It is documented that interaction with an animal (not a Cujo, and not necessarily a dog) can provide  calm comfort, much like you are describing the effects of peaceful music.   http://www.americanhumane.org/human-animal-bond/programs/animal-assisted-therapy  Obviously, friends' pets can provide this, as long as they are not psycho barking obnoxious dogs.  Therapy dogs are pets whose temperament and  behavior are soothing/therapeutic to people in need of it.  Our center actually tests and certifies the pets, but as any pet owner knows, many of our pets provide that to us. The volunteers who use their  dogs as therapy dogs are generous, kind people. In NJ, our center coordinates visits to various facilities, included Carol Simon Cancer center in Morristown, visiting patients in treatment and their families as well.  I know many teams in NJ who would visit homes for people like us: emotionally in need of comfort. I know this all sounds silly, in light of your needs right now; but this is a simple, sweet, deep comfort that is overlooked.  There already be teams visiting a local out-patient facility near you.  You don't have to be in a hospital bed to benefit from this. I will be thinking about you.  We are both facing a frightening situation, mine looming just after yours.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 10:06AM SofieKatz wrote: My hair's been growing since 9 months.  I've colored it twice. This is what I do to manage the curls: While very wet,  I put leave-in conditioner, but not one that softens the hair too much. Then I flatten my hair like a back-to-front combover and dry it that way, using my hands and fingers to flatten it forward.  When dry, I use my fingers to push it back towards the crown.  It's straight and thatchy.  I put a little light finishing paste on the top and pull the hair so it is thatchy and stands up.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 08:09AM SofieKatz wrote: Don't mean to be the fun-sucker, but I've been thinking about my hair for the last couple months.  It's been growing back since Mid-May and I had it trimmed and colored 3 weeks ago.  My hair was my favorite thing  about me.  I loved my hair.  My hair defined me.  Now it is not mine and I am not me.  I hate it and can't even look in the miror.   I don't wash it for days at a time so it is less fuzzy.   People tell me it looks "cute" which makes me cringe.   I keep most of it covered with a buff and I wear lots of garish eye makeup so people notice my garish eyes and not my ugly self.  That's all.  My best wishes to all of you, from my heart.  Glad you are recovering.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: SofieKatz wrote: Hi, I know this is discussed elsewhere, but I can't find it. It's been exactly 4 weeks since my bilateral mastectomy and  lymphectomies.   Pain is gone; still tight in lymph arm, but working on that with stretching.  I went in 12 days ago to drain 800cc fluid from my surgical sites, and that put me back for sure.  But that is also healing nicely. But:  my stamina is so poor!  If I go out for lunch or just to visit with friends, by three hours I am exhausted and literally physically longing for my recliner.   How long does it take to be able to at least last three hours without crashing?  I have always been a physically and emotionally strong person, but I feel like I will never get strong again  Lucky I can work from home, because the idea of spending any time at my desk makes me very anxious, knowing how tired I get. Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2011 04:20PM - edited Sep 5, 2011 04:21PM by SofieKatz I had 4 doses of AC over 8 weeks, then 12 weeks of taxol.  My hair statred growing as soon as I stopped AC and started taxol.    The growth started almost imperceptibly (I did not realize it would grow so fast!) and unevenly.  The top takes longer to fill in, but grows daily.   Throughout chemo I washed my head and used a Trader Joe's "tingly" mint conditioner.  I also started biotin with taxol.  I am also using a botanical leave-in conditioner.  However, I don't believe that had anything to do with it, other than care for my pathetic sclalp.   However,  I am using more shampoo and actually have wet hair after a wash. I am almost 6 weeks post-taxol, so basically my hair has been growing for 18 weeks and I am nowhere near going wigless.  I figure I will get a cut and color sometime in December.  Before that (probably in mid-October) I will have my friend (who is my stylist) trim off the soft ends to give it more body. The hair on my arms and legs are back.  Eyelashes 1/2 there.  Eyebrows not so much.     Let me add:  Chemo kicked my ass.  Taxol was much easier, but as the weeks bore on, I wore out.  (Also, the last 3 weeks of Taxol I ran a children's day camp of 48 kids.)  So basically having my hair begin to grow early was the only good thing that happened.    From what I read here, everyone is different in their treatment.   So that's just my experience.
